natural problem: There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Each time Sam presses the big red button on the machine, the machine randomly selects one of the remaining toys and gives Sam the option to buy it. If Sam has enough money, he will buy the toy, the red button will light up again, and he can repeat the process. If Sam has 8 quarters and a ten dollar bill and the machine only accepts quarters, what is the probability that Sam has to get change for the 10 dollar bill before he can buy his favorite toy- the one that costs $\$1.75$? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: We will calculate the probability that Sam can buy his favorite toy just using his 8 quarters and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed.

If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!

orderings of the toys that let him buy his favorite just using the quarters. If the first toy is the one that only costs 25 cents, then he will be able to buy his favorite toy just using his remaining quarters if and only if it is the second one dispensed.

If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.

If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.

So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes remaining_toys p_fav_toy :: nat
assumes h0 : "remaining_toys = 8"
and h1 : "p_fav_toy = 6"
shows  "probability_get_change = (p_fav_toy / (remaining_toys - 1))"
a_0.formal solution:

 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability that Sam can buy his favorite toy just using his 8 quarters and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed.
 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!

 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes remaining_toys p_fav_toy :: nat
assumes h0 : "remaining_toys = 8"
and h1 : "p_fav_toy = 6"
shows  "probability_get_change = (p_fav_toy / (remaining_toys - 1))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If there are 8 remaining toys and 6 of them are your favorite toy, what is the probability of getting your favorite toy after one has been taken away? The final answer is given as a fraction: $\frac{6}{(8 - 1)}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and total_toys :: nat
and quarters :: nat
and ten_dollar_bill :: real
and sam_money :: real
and favorite_toy_cost :: real
assumes h0 : "total_toys = 8"
and h1 : "quarters = 8"
and h2 : "ten_dollar_bill = 10"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. (i > 0 \<and> i < total_toys) \<longrightarrow> toys i = 0.25 * i"
and h4 : "favorite_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h5 : "sam_money = 0.25 * quarters"
and h6 : "favorite_toy_cost > sam_money"
shows  "P(need_change_for_10_dollar_bill) = 6 / 7"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof

 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!
 orderings of the toys that let him buy his favorite just using the quarters. If the first toy is the one that only costs 25 cents, then he will be able to buy his favorite toy just using his remaining quarters if and only if it is the second one dispensed.
 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.

 *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and total_toys :: nat
and quarters :: nat
and ten_dollar_bill :: real
and sam_money :: real
and favorite_toy_cost :: real
assumes h0 : "total_toys = 8"
and h1 : "quarters = 8"
and h2 : "ten_dollar_bill = 10"
and h3 : "\<forall> i. (i > 0 \<and> i < total_toys) \<longrightarrow> toys i = 0.25 * i"
and h4 : "favorite_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h5 : "sam_money = 0.25 * quarters"
and h6 : "favorite_toy_cost > sam_money"
shows  "P(need_change_for_10_dollar_bill) = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Sam has 8 toys, and each toy costs $0.25i$ for $i > 0$ and $i < 8$. Sam also has 8 quarters and a $10 bill. Sam's favorite toy costs $1.75, but he doesn't have enough money in quarters to buy it. What is the probability that Sam needs change for his $10 bill to buy a toy? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability = 6 / 7"
shows  "probability = (6::real) / 7"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Each time Sam presses the big red button on the machine, the machine randomly selects one of the remaining toys and gives Sam the option to buy it. If Sam has enough money, he will buy the toy, the red button will light up again, and he can repeat the process. Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof

 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!
 orderings of the toys that let him buy his favorite just using the quarters. If the first toy is the one that only costs 25 cents, then he will be able to buy his favorite toy just using his remaining quarters if and only if it is the second one dispensed.
 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability = 6 / 7"
shows  "probability = (6::real) / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that the probability of an event is a real number between 0 and 1, find the value of the probability if it is equal to $\frac{6}{7}$. The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "rat list" and favorite_toy_cost :: rat
assumes h0 : "length toys = 8"
and h1 : "sorted_wrt (\<le>) toys"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < length toys - 1 \<longrightarrow> toys!(Suc i) - toys!i = 1/4"
and h3 : "favorite_toy_cost = 7 / 4"
and h4 : "hd toys = 1"
and h5 : "8 * (1 / 4) \<le> favorite_toy_cost"
shows  "probability_favorite_toy_before_change = 6 / 7"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes toys :: "rat list" and favorite_toy_cost :: rat
assumes h0 : "length toys = 8"
and h1 : "sorted_wrt (\<le>) toys"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. i < length toys - 1 \<longrightarrow> toys!(Suc i) - toys!i = 1/4"
and h3 : "favorite_toy_cost = 7 / 4"
and h4 : "hd toys = 1"
and h5 : "8 * (1 / 4) \<le> favorite_toy_cost"
shows  "probability_favorite_toy_before_change = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are 8 toys in a row, and their prices are sorted in ascending order. The difference in price between each consecutive pair of toys is $1/4$. The price of the favorite toy is $7/4$. Initially, the price of the first toy is $1$. If the price of the favorite toy is at least $8 * (1/4)$, what is the probability that the favorite toy is one of the first 6 toys in the row? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "real list"
and favorite_toy_cost :: real
and quarters :: nat
and ten_dollar_bill :: real
assumes h0 : "length toys = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall>i < length toys - 1. toys ! i + 0.25 = toys ! (i + 1)"
and h2 : "favorite_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h3 : "quarters = 8"
and h4 : "ten_dollar_bill = 10"
shows  "probability_favorite_toy_requires_change = 6 / 7"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one.  *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "real list"
and favorite_toy_cost :: real
and quarters :: nat
and ten_dollar_bill :: real
assumes h0 : "length toys = 8"
and h1 : "\<forall>i < length toys - 1. toys ! i + 0.25 = toys ! (i + 1)"
and h2 : "favorite_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h3 : "quarters = 8"
and h4 : "ten_dollar_bill = 10"
shows  "probability_favorite_toy_requires_change = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A child has 8 toys in a row and the cost of each toy increases by 25 cents from the previous one. The cost of their favorite toy is $1.75. If the child has 8 quarters and a ten-dollar bill, find the probability that the child will need to get change if they buy their favorite toy. The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "toys 0 = 0.25"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> n < 8 \<longrightarrow> toys (n + 1) = toys n + 0.25"
and h2 : "8 * (0.25 :: real) = 2"
and h3 : "toys 7 = 1.75"
shows  "P (Sam_has_to_get_change_for_10_dollar_bill) = (6 / 7)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Each time Sam presses the big red button on the machine, the machine randomly selects one of the remaining toys and gives Sam the option to buy it. If Sam has enough money, he will buy the toy, the red button will light up again, and he can repeat the process. If Sam has 8 quarters and a ten dollar bill and the machine only accepts quarters, what is the probability that Sam has to get change for the 10 dollar bill before he can buy his favorite toy- the one that costs $\$1.75$? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability that Sam can buy his favorite toy just using his 8 quarters and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed.
 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!

 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "toys 0 = 0.25"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> n < 8 \<longrightarrow> toys (n + 1) = toys n + 0.25"
and h2 : "8 * (0.25 :: real) = 2"
and h3 : "toys 7 = 1.75"
shows  "P (Sam_has_to_get_change_for_10_dollar_bill) = (6 / 7)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Sam has a collection of toys that he bought at a store. He started with a toy that cost $0.25, and with each subsequent toy he bought, he spent $0.25 more than the previous toy. Sam bought a total of 8 toys, spending a total of $2. If he had a $10 bill, what is the probability that Sam has to get change for the $10 bill after buying the 7th toy? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and sam_money :: real
and machine_accepts :: real
and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "sam_money = 8 * 0.25 + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> toys n = 0.25 * n"
and h2 : "machine_accepts = 0.25"
and h3 : "prob = (\<Sum>n \<in> {n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 7}. (1 / (8 - n + 1))) / 7"
and h4 : "toys 7 = 1.75"
shows  "prob = 6 / 7"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Each time Sam presses the big red button on the machine, the machine randomly selects one of the remaining toys and gives Sam the option to buy it. If Sam has enough money, he will buy the toy, the red button will light up again, and he can repeat the process. If Sam has 8 quarters and a ten dollar bill and the machine only accepts quarters, what is the probability that Sam has to get change for the 10 dollar bill before he can buy his favorite toy- the one that costs $\$1.75$? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability that Sam can buy his favorite toy just using his 8 quarters and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed.
 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!

 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and sam_money :: real
and machine_accepts :: real
and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "sam_money = 8 * 0.25 + 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> toys n = 0.25 * n"
and h2 : "machine_accepts = 0.25"
and h3 : "prob = (\<Sum>n \<in> {n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 7}. (1 / (8 - n + 1))) / 7"
and h4 : "toys 7 = 1.75"
shows  "prob = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Sam has $8 * 0.25 + 10$ dollars. There are 8 toys in a machine that cost $0.25 * n$ dollars each, where $n$ is the toy number from 1 to 8. The machine accepts $0.25$ dollars at a time. Sam gets a toy with number 7, which costs $1.75$ dollars. What is the probability that Sam gets the toy with number 7 in the next try? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 0 \<le> n \<and> n < 8 \<longrightarrow> toys n = 0.25 * (n + 1)"
and h1 : "toys 6 = 1.75"
and h2 : "8 * 0.25 \<le> 1.75"
and h3 : "random_sel :: nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and h4 : "random_sel 8 = 6"
shows  "probability = 6 / 7"
a_7.formal solution:

 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. 0 \<le> n \<and> n < 8 \<longrightarrow> toys n = 0.25 * (n + 1)"
and h1 : "toys 6 = 1.75"
and h2 : "8 * 0.25 \<le> 1.75"
and h3 : "random_sel :: nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and h4 : "random_sel 8 = 6"
shows  "probability = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A toy store has a promotion where they randomly select one of 8 toys to give away. The probability of selecting each toy is proportional to its weight, with a weight of $0.25(n+1)$, where $n$ is the index of the toy (from 0 to 7). The 6th toy has a weight of 1.75, and the total weight of the 8 toys is at least 1.75. If the random selection process chose the 6th toy, what is the probability of this occurrence? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and sam_money :: real and sam_quarters :: int and fav_toy_cost :: real
assumes h0 : "sam_money = 10"
and h1 : "sam_quarters = 8"
and h2 : "fav_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. (1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8) \<longrightarrow> (toys i = 0.25 * i + 0.25)"
and h4 : "toys 7 = fav_toy_cost"
shows  "P(sam_gets_change) = 6 / 7"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Each time Sam presses the big red button on the machine, the machine randomly selects one of the remaining toys and gives Sam the option to buy it. If Sam has enough money, he will buy the toy, the red button will light up again, and he can repeat the process. If Sam has 8 quarters and a ten dollar bill and the machine only accepts quarters, what is the probability that Sam has to get change for the 10 dollar bill before he can buy his favorite toy- the one that costs $\$1.75$? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability that Sam can buy his favorite toy just using his 8 quarters and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed.
 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!
 orderings of the toys that let him buy his favorite just using the quarters. If the first toy is the one that only costs 25 cents, then he will be able to buy his favorite toy just using his remaining quarters if and only if it is the second one dispensed.
 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and sam_money :: real and sam_quarters :: int and fav_toy_cost :: real
assumes h0 : "sam_money = 10"
and h1 : "sam_quarters = 8"
and h2 : "fav_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h3 : "\<forall>i. (1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 8) \<longrightarrow> (toys i = 0.25 * i + 0.25)"
and h4 : "toys 7 = fav_toy_cost"
shows  "P(sam_gets_change) = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Sam has $10 and 8 quarters. His favorite toy costs $1.75. Each of the 8 quarters increases the cost of the toy by $0.25 + 0.25i$ where i is the number of quarters already used. If Sam uses 7 quarters to buy the toy, what is the probability that he gets change? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "toys 1 = 0.25"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n < 8 \<longrightarrow> toys (n + 1) = toys n + 0.25"
and h2 : "toys 8 = 2.00"
and h3 : "Sam_quarters = 8"
and h4 : "Sam_ten_dollar_bill = 10"
and h5 : "favorite_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h6 : "machine_accepts_quarters"
and h7 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> P (toys n) = 1 / 8"
shows  "P (favorite_toy_cost) = 6 / 7"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 There is a machine with 8 toys in it that each cost between 25 cents and 2 dollars, with each toy being 25 cents more expensive than the next most expensive one. Each time Sam presses the big red button on the machine, the machine randomly selects one of the remaining toys and gives Sam the option to buy it. If Sam has enough money, he will buy the toy, the red button will light up again, and he can repeat the process. If Sam has 8 quarters and a ten dollar bill and the machine only accepts quarters, what is the probability that Sam has to get change for the 10 dollar bill before he can buy his favorite toy- the one that costs $\$1.75$? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \dfrac{6}{7}
 ### Proof
 We will calculate the probability that Sam can buy his favorite toy just using his 8 quarters and then subtract that from 1 to get the probability that we're looking for. There are a total of $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed.
 If his favorite toy is the first one that the machine selects, then he can obviously buy it just using his quarters, and then there are $7!$ order in which the other toys can be dispensed, which gives us 7!
 orderings of the toys that let him buy his favorite just using the quarters. If the first toy is the one that only costs 25 cents, then he will be able to buy his favorite toy just using his remaining quarters if and only if it is the second one dispensed.
 If those are the first two toys dispensed, there are $6!$ ways to order the other toys which means that we have another $6!$ orderings of the toys that allow him to buy his favorite toy without getting change for the 10 dollar bill.
 If the first toy costs more than 25 cents, or if two toys are dispensed before his favorite one, then he won't have enough quarters to buy his favorite one without getting change for his ten dollar bill.
 So out of the $8!$ orders in which the 8 toys can be dispensed, there are $7! + 6!$ ways that allow him to buy his favorite toy just using his quarters for a probability of $\dfrac{7!+6!}{8!}=\dfrac{6!}{6!}\cdot\dfrac{7+1}{8\cdot7}=\dfrac{1}{7}$.
 But that is the probability that what we want $\emph{doesn't}$ happen, so we need to subtract it from 1 to get our final probability of $1-\dfrac{1}{7}=\boxed{\dfrac{6}{7}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes toys :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "toys 1 = 0.25"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n < 8 \<longrightarrow> toys (n + 1) = toys n + 0.25"
and h2 : "toys 8 = 2.00"
and h3 : "Sam_quarters = 8"
and h4 : "Sam_ten_dollar_bill = 10"
and h5 : "favorite_toy_cost = 1.75"
and h6 : "machine_accepts_quarters"
and h7 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 8 \<longrightarrow> P (toys n) = 1 / 8"
shows  "P (favorite_toy_cost) = 6 / 7"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Sam has 8 quarters and a 10-dollar bill. He wants to buy his favorite toy from a machine that only accepts quarters. The machine has 8 toys, with the first toy costing 25 cents and each subsequent toy costing 25 cents more than the previous one. The eighth toy costs 2 dollars. The probability of Sam getting any of the 8 toys is equal, at 1/8. If Sam's favorite toy costs 1.75 dollars, what is the probability that he will get it? The final answer is $\frac{6}{7}$.
